docs.title: FinWise Python SDK
docs.text:
Unofficial Python SDK for the FinWise API

Unofficial SDK

This is an unofficial, community-maintained Python SDK for the FinWise API. It is not affiliated with, endorsed by, or officially supported by FinWise.

A simple, type-safe Python client for the FinWise API.

For the official API documentation, see finwiseapp.io/docs/api.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Type-safe: Full type hints and Pydantic models
  • Automatic retries: Exponential backoff for transient errors
  • Pagination support: Easy iteration through paginated results
  • Context manager: Automatic resource cleanup

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

# List all accounts
accounts = client.accounts.list()
for account in accounts.data:
    print(f"{account.name}: {account.currency} {account.balance}")

docs.text:
• Python 3.9+

docs.title: Client Options
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(
    api_key="your-api-key",
    base_url="https://api.finwiseapp.io",  # Default
    timeout=30.0,    # Request timeout in seconds
    max_retries=3,   # Automatic retries for transient errors
)
Parameter Type Default Description api_key str None Your FinWise API key. Falls back to FINWISE_API_KEY env var base_url str https://api.finwiseapp.io API base URL timeout float 30.0 Request timeout in seconds max_retries int 3 Number of retries for transient errors

docs.title: Environment Variable
docs.text:
Set your API key via environment variable to avoid hardcoding it:

export FINWISE_API_KEY="your-api-key"

from finwise import FinWise

# Automatically uses FINWISE_API_KEY
client = FinWise()

docs.title: Context Manager
docs.text:
Use the client as a context manager for automatic cleanup:

from finwise import FinWise

with FinWise(api_key="your-api-key") as client:
    accounts = client.accounts.list()
    # Client is automatically closed when exiting the block

This ensures the underlying HTTP connection is properly closed when you're done.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: • Python 3.11 or higher

docs.title: From PyPI
docs.text:
Install the SDK using pip:

pip install finwise-python

docs.title: Using Nix
docs.text:
If you have Nix installed with flakes enabled, you can use this package directly:

# Build the package
nix build github:rameezk/finwise-python

# Or use in your flake.nix
{
  inputs.finwise-python.url = "github:rameezk/finwise-python";
}

docs.title: For Development
docs.text:
If you want to contribute or modify the SDK:

pip install finwise-python[dev]

Or with Nix:

git clone https://github.com/rameezk/finwise-python.git
cd finwise-python
nix develop
pip install -e .

docs.title: For Documentation
docs.text:
To build the documentation locally:

pip install finwise-python[docs]

Or with Nix:

nix develop .#docs
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Handle Errors
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise, NotFoundError

client = FinWise()

try:
    account = client.accounts.retrieve("invalid_id")
except NotFoundError as e:
    print(f"Account not found: {e.message}")

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text: The SDK provides a comprehensive exception hierarchy for handling errors.

docs.title: Exception Hierarchy
docs.text:
FinWiseError (base)
├── FinWiseAPIError (API returned an error)
│   ├── AuthenticationError (401)
│   ├── PermissionDeniedError (403)
│   ├── NotFoundError (404)
│   ├── ValidationError (400, 422)
│   ├── ConflictError (409)
│   ├── RateLimitError (429)
│   └── ServerError (5xx)
├── FinWiseConnectionError (connection failed)
└── FinWiseTimeoutError (request timed out)

docs.title: Usage Example
docs.text:
from finwise import (
    FinWise,
    FinWiseError,
    FinWiseAPIError,
    AuthenticationError,
    PermissionDeniedError,
    NotFoundError,
    ValidationError,
    ConflictError,
    RateLimitError,
    ServerError,
    FinWiseConnectionError,
    FinWiseTimeoutError,
)

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

try:
    account = client.accounts.retrieve("invalid_id")
except NotFoundError as e:
    print(f"Not found: {e.message}")
    print(f"Request ID: {e.request_id}")  # For debugging
except AuthenticationError as e:
    print(f"Auth failed: {e.message}")
except RateLimitError as e:
    print(f"Rate limited. Retry after: {e.retry_after}s")
except FinWiseAPIError as e:
    print(f"API error {e.status_code}: {e.message}")
except FinWiseConnectionError as e:
    print(f"Connection failed: {e.message}")
except FinWiseError as e:
    print(f"Error: {e.message}")

docs.title: FinWiseAPIError
docs.text: Property Type Description message str Error message from the API status_code int HTTP status code request_id str Unique request ID for debugging

docs.title: RateLimitError
docs.text: Property Type Description retry_after int Seconds to wait before retrying

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Catch specific exceptions first, then broader ones
  2. Log the request_id when reporting issues to support
  3. Handle RateLimitError by waiting retry_after seconds
  4. Use FinWiseError as a catch-all for SDK errors

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text: All list methods return a PaginatedResponse object for easy iteration through results.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

# Get first page
accounts = client.accounts.list(page_number=1, page_size=50)

print(f"Page {accounts.page_number} of {accounts.total_pages}")
print(f"Showing {len(accounts)} of {accounts.total_count} accounts")

docs.title: PaginatedResponse Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description data list Items on the current page page_number int Current page number (1-indexed) page_size int Items per page total_count int Total items across all pages total_pages int Total number of pages has_next bool Whether there's a next page has_previous bool Whether there's a previous page

docs.title: Iterating Through Items
docs.text:
# Iterate through items on this page
for account in accounts.data:
    print(account.name)

# Or iterate directly on the response
for account in accounts:
    print(account.name)

# Access by index
first_account = accounts[0]  # or accounts.data[0]

docs.title: Fetching Multiple Pages
docs.text:
# Check for more pages
if accounts.has_next:
    next_page = client.accounts.list(
        page_number=accounts.page_number + 1,
        page_size=50,
    )

docs.title: Iterating Through All Pages
docs.text:
page_number = 1
all_accounts = []

while True:
    accounts = client.accounts.list(
        page_number=page_number,
        page_size=100
    )
    all_accounts.extend(accounts.data)

    if not accounts.has_next:
        break
    page_number += 1

print(f"Fetched {len(all_accounts)} accounts")

docs.title: Account Balances
docs.text: Track point-in-time balance snapshots for accounts.

docs.title: Create a Balance Record
docs.text:
from decimal import Decimal
from datetime import date
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

balance = client.account_balances.create(
    account_id="acc_123",
    balance=Decimal("5000.00"),
    balance_date=date(2024, 1, 15),
)

When to Use Balance Records

Balance records are useful for:

  • Tracking account balances over time
  • Reconciling with bank statements
  • Building net worth history

docs.title: List Balance Records
docs.text:
balances = client.account_balances.list(account_id="acc_123")

for balance in balances.data:
    print(f"{balance.balance_date}: {balance.balance}")

docs.title: Get Aggregated Balance
docs.text:
Get the total balance across all accounts:

summary = client.account_balances.aggregated()
print(f"Total: {summary.currency} {summary.total_balance}")
print(f"Across {summary.account_count} accounts")

You can also get the balance as of a specific date:

summary = client.account_balances.aggregated(
    as_of_date=date(2024, 1, 31)
)

docs.title: Archive a Balance Record
docs.text: client.account_balances.archive("bal_123")

docs.title: Accounts
docs.text: Manage financial accounts (checking, savings, credit cards, etc.).

docs.title: Create an Account
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

account = client.accounts.create(
    name="Savings Account",
    type="savings",
    currency="USD",
    description="Emergency fund",
    initial_balance=10000.00,
)
print(f"Created: {account.id}")

docs.title: Account Types
docs.text: Type Description checking Checking/current account savings Savings account credit Credit card investment Investment/brokerage account loan Loan account other Other account type

docs.title: Retrieve an Account
docs.text:
account = client.accounts.retrieve("acc_123")
print(f"{account.name}: {account.balance}")

docs.title: Update an Account
docs.text:
account = client.accounts.update(
    "acc_123",
    name="Renamed Account",
    description="Updated description",
)

docs.title: List Accounts
docs.text:
# Basic listing
accounts = client.accounts.list()
for account in accounts.data:
    print(f"  - {account.name}")

# With pagination
accounts = client.accounts.list(page_number=1, page_size=50)
print(f"Total accounts: {accounts.total_count}")

if accounts.has_next:
    next_page = client.accounts.list(page_number=2, page_size=50)

docs.title: Archive an Account
docs.text:
archived = client.accounts.archive("acc_123")
print(f"Archived at: {archived.archived_at}")

Note

Archiving is a soft delete. The account data is preserved but hidden from normal listings.

docs.title: Transaction Categories
docs.text: Organize transactions with categories and subcategories.

docs.title: Create a Category
docs.text:
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

category = client.transaction_categories.create(
    name="Groceries",
    color="#4CAF50",
    icon="shopping_cart",
)

docs.title: Create a Subcategory
docs.text:
subcategory = client.transaction_categories.create(
    name="Organic Food",
    color="#8BC34A",
    parent_id=category.id,
)

docs.title: List Categories
docs.text:
categories = client.transaction_categories.list()

for cat in categories.data:
    prefix = "  " if cat.is_subcategory else ""
    print(f"{prefix}{cat.name}")

To list only subcategories of a specific parent:

subcategories = client.transaction_categories.list(
    parent_id="cat_groceries"
)

docs.title: Delete a Category
docs.text:
client.transaction_categories.delete("cat_123")

Warning

Deleting a category will remove it permanently. Transactions using this category will have their category reference cleared.

docs.title: Transactions
docs.text: Record and query financial transactions.

docs.title: Create a Transaction
docs.text:
from decimal import Decimal
from datetime import date
from finwise import FinWise

client = FinWise(api_key="your-api-key")

transaction = client.transactions.create(
    account_id="acc_123",
    amount=Decimal("-50.00"),  # Negative for expenses
    transaction_date=date.today(),
    description="Grocery shopping",
    category_id="cat_groceries",
    type="expense",
)

docs.title: Transaction Types
docs.text:
Type Description income Money coming in expense Money going out transfer Transfer between accounts

Amount Sign Convention

Use negative amounts for expenses and positive amounts for income. This makes calculations straightforward.

docs.title: List Transactions
docs.text:
# Basic listing
transactions = client.transactions.list(account_id="acc_123")

# With date filters
transactions = client.transactions.list(
    account_id="acc_123",
    start_date=date(2024, 1, 1),
    end_date=date(2024, 1, 31),
    type="expense",
)

for txn in transactions.data:
    print(f"{txn.transaction_date}: {txn.description} ({txn.amount})")

docs.title: Get Aggregated Summary
docs.text:
Get totals for a date range:

summary = client.transactions.aggregated(
    start_date=date(2024, 1, 1),
    end_date=date(2024, 1, 31),
)
print(f"Income: {summary.total_income}")
print(f"Expenses: {summary.total_expenses}")
print(f"Net: {summary.net_amount}")

docs.title: Archive a Transaction
docs.text: client.transactions.archive("txn_123")
